EREP.selectionTitle: The landlord is not completing emergency repairs that were ordered by the Residential Tenancy Branch or other BC Authority (i.e., Local Government, Fire Department, etc.) or after the landlord has been made aware of the required emergency repairs
EREP.issueTitle: The landlord is not completing emergency repairs that were ordered by the Residential Tenancy Branch or other BC Authority (i.e., Local Government, Fire Department, etc.) or after the landlord has been made aware of the required emergency repairs
EREP.selectionHelp:
Emergency repairs are repairs that are necessary for the health and safety of anyone in the residential property or park.

Emergency repairs include:
  • Majors leaks in pipes or the roof,
  • Damaged or blocked water or sewer pipes,
  • The primary heating system (only under the Residential Tenancy Act),
  • Damaged or defective locks that give access to the rental unit (only under the Residential Tenancy Act), and
  • The electrical systems.

Learn more about emergency repairs and maintenance.

RREP.selectionTitle: The landlord is not completing non-emergency repairs that were ordered by the Residential Tenancy Branch or other BC Authority (i.e., Local Government, Fire Department, etc.) or after the landlord has been made aware of the required emergency repairs
RREP.issueTitle: The landlord is not completing non-emergency repairs that were ordered by the Residential Tenancy Branch or other BC Authority (i.e., Local Government, Fire Department, etc.) or after the landlord has been made aware of the required emergency repairs
RREP.selectionHelp:
Landlords are responsible for maintenance of the rental property and completing repairs after receiving a written request from the tenant. If a landlord does not complete the repair, the tenant can apply for dispute resolution with the Residential Tenancy Branch.

Learn more about repairs and maintenance.

NCOD-L.selectionTitle: The landlord is failing to comply with a decision or order of the Residential Tenancy Branch
NCOD-L.issueTitle: The landlord is failing to comply with a decision or order of the Residential Tenancy Branch
NCOD-L.selectionHelp:
Failure to comply with a decision or order of the Residential Tenancy Branch is a contravention of the law. The Compliance and Enforcement Unit does not enforce Residential Tenancy Branch orders.

Residential Tenancy Branch orders are enforced through the Provincial Courts. Learn more about enforcing orders.

MNTE.selectionTitle: The landlord has served multiple notices to end tenancy or has made multiple threats of eviction
MNTE.issueTitle: The landlord has served multiple notices to end tenancy or has made multiple threats of eviction
MNTE.selectionHelp: Quiet enjoyment means that tenants have a right to peace, quiet, and privacy in their homes. Landlords serving multiple eviction notices without cause can violate a tenant's right to quiet enjoyment. To obtain a monetary order, you must file an application for dispute resolution with the Residential Tenancy Branch.

ILRI.selectionTitle: The landlord is charging illegal rent increases
ILRI.issueTitle: The landlord is charging illegal rent increases
ILRI.selectionHelp: Landlords can increase rent once in a 12-month period by the maximum allowable amount or an amount approved by a Residential Tenancy Branch arbitrator. Landlords must provide three months' notice of a rent increase. Landlords cannot raise rent above the allowable amount between fixed term tenancies with the same tenant. For more information on what rent increases are allowed, see the Residential Tenancy Branch website.

CHFE.issueTitle: The landlord is charging unlawful fees, such as application fees or fees for assignment or sublet
CHFE.selectionHelp: Landlords cannot charge fees for accepting, reviewing, or processing a tenancy application, keys, having guests, or costs related to returning a deposit.
CHFE.issueHelp: Landlords cannot charge fees for accepting, reviewing, or processing a tenancy application, keys, having guests, or costs related to returning a deposit.

LOCK.selectionTitle: The landlord has locked a tenant out of their unit or the park
LOCK.issueTitle: The landlord has locked a tenant out of their unit or the park
LOCK.selectionHelp:
Landlords cannot change locks unless the tenant agrees, and the landlord provides new keys to the unit. The Compliance and Enforcement Unit cannot issue an order of possession for a rental unit. Tenants can apply for an order of possession if their landlord locks them out of their unit by filing for dispute resolution with the Residential Tenancy Branch.

Learn more about possession of a rental unit or site.
LOCK.issueHelp:

Tenants can apply for an order of possession if their landlord locks them out of their unit by filing for dispute resolution with the Residential Tenancy Branch.

Learn more about possession of a rental unit or site.

TESR.selectionTitle: The landlord is denying access to essential services (e.g., power, water)
TESR.issueTitle: The landlord is denying access to essential services (e.g., power, water)
TESR.selectionHelp:
Landlords must provide and maintain services that are essential to the health and safety of the tenant or are necessary to make the rental unit liveable. These services include heat, water, and electricity. You may be entitled to compensation or a rent reduction if your landlord has restricted an essential service. To obtain a monetary order or a rent reduction, you must apply for dispute resolution with the Residential Tenancy Branch.

Learn more about changes to the agreement.

LEWN.selectionTitle: The landlord is repeatedly entering the rental unit/site without proper notice
LEWN.issueTitle: The landlord is repeatedly entering the rental unit/site without proper notice
LEWN.selectionHelp:
Landlords must provide proper notice to the tenant to enter the rental unit or site. Proper notice means a tenant is given written notice of the date, time, and purpose for entering the property. The tenant must receive this notice at least 24 hours before the landlord enters the unit or site. For more information, see Policy Guideline 7. Tenants can request an order for the landlord to comply with the law and to allow the tenant to change the locks on a rental unit or set conditions on a landlord's right to enter a manufactured home site. To do this, you must apply for dispute resolution with the Residential Tenancy Branch.

Learn more about unlawful access.

RESG.selectionTitle: The landlord is unreasonably restricting guest access to the rental unit, manufactured home site, or common areas
RESG.issueTitle: The landlord is unreasonably restricting guest access to the rental unit, manufactured home site, or common areas
RESG.selectionHelp:
A landlord cannot stop tenants from having guests under reasonable circumstances. A landlord cannot impose restrictions on guests or require a fee for guests to stay overnight. Under BC tenancy law, tenants can request an order for the landlord to comply with the law. To do this, you must apply for dispute resolution with the Residential Tenancy Branch.

Learn more about guests during tenancies.

SIPP.issueTitle: The landlord is withholding, seizing, or blocking access to the tenant's belongings
SIPP.selectionHelp: Landlords cannot seize a tenant's personal property or prevent or interfere with a tenant's access to their personal property, even if a tenant has not paid their rent. Tenants can request an order for the landlord to return their belonging. To do this, you must apply for dispute resolution with the Residential Tenancy Branch.

FRAU-L.selectionTitle: The landlord has given false or misleading information to the Residential Tenancy Branch
FRAU-L.issueTitle: The landlord has given false or misleading information to the Residential Tenancy Branch
FRAU-L.selectionHelp: The Compliance and Enforcement Unit may investigate allegations of landlords providing false or misleading information submitted in a dispute resolution proceeding or an investigation. The Compliance and Enforcement Unit can issue warnings and administrative monetary penalties to have landlords comply with BC tenancy laws. The Compliance and Enforcement Unit is not an alternative to dispute resolution and cannot change or modify a decision. If you feel the arbitrator's decision was based on fraud, you must apply for review with the Residential Tenancy Branch.

BFNO.issueTitle: The landlord is attempting to end a tenancy in ways not allowed under BC tenancy laws, repeatedly or for numerous tenants
BFNO.selectionHelp: The Compliance and Enforcement Unit cannot cancel a Notice to End Tenancy. For more information on how a tenancy can end, see the Residential Tenancy Branch. Tenants can dispute a Notice to End Tenancy by applying for dispute resolution with the Residential Tenancy Branch.

CHPR.selectionTitle: The landlord is changing Park Rules in a manner that contravenes BC tenancy laws
CHPR.issueTitle: The landlord is changing Park Rules in a manner that contravenes BC tenancy laws
CHPR.selectionHelp: A park committee or a landlord (if there is no park committee) can establish, change or repeal manufactured home park rules. Park rules must be consistent with the Manufactured Home Park Tenancy Act or a term in a tenancy agreement. If park rules contravene the Act, tenants may apply for dispute resolution through the Residential Tenancy Branch.

LOCA.issueTitle: The landlord has engaged in other activities contrary to the BC tenancy laws

For more information on your rights and responsibilities under the tenancy legislation, please see the Residential Tenancy Branch website. You can also contact the Residential Tenancy Branch.

NPOR.selectionTitle: The tenant has repeatedly not paid rent
NPOR.issueTitle: The tenant has repeatedly not paid rent
NPOR.selectionHelp:
Tenants must pay rent in full when it is due.

Landlords can serve a 10 Day Notice to End Tenancy when tenants do not pay their rent on time. Submitting a complaint through the Compliance and Enforcement Unit is not a substitute for the dispute resolution process.

Learn more about ending a tenancy.

DAPR.issueTitle: The tenant has caused serious or repeated damage to the rental unit/site, or common areas
DAPR.selectionHelp:
Landlords can end a tenancy for cause if a tenant has caused significant damage to the rental unit or site, or the landlord's property. Landlords can apply for an expedited hearing if tenants are causing significant damage to the property.

Learn more about expedited hearings.

The Compliance and Enforcement Unit does not enforce orders for possession or money. For more information on enforcing orders see the Residential Tenancy Branch website

ASWP.selectionHelp:
Tenants cannot assign a tenancy agreement or sublet a rental unit or site without permission from the landlord. If a tenant assigns or sublets without permission, the landlord can serve a Notice to End Tenancy for cause.

Learn more about sublets and assignments.

E014004.title: Decision(s) or order(s)
E014004.helpHtml: Provide a copy of the decision and/or order from the Residential Tenancy Branch.

E014005.title: RTB dispute documents
E014005.helpHtml: Provide copies of evidence uploaded to the Residential Tenancy Branch Dispute File that is relevant to the false or misleading information.

E014006.title: Tenancy agreements
E014006.helpHtml: Provide a copy of the most recent Tenancy Agreement outlining the terms of the tenancy. Include any addendums.

E015001.title: Notice(s) to end tenancy
E015001.helpHtml: Provide a copy of the notice, or communication given by the landlord or agent.

E015002.title: Tenancy agreements
E015002.helpHtml: Provide a copy of the most recent Tenancy Agreement outlining the terms of the tenancy. Include any addendums.

E016001.title: Original rules
E016001.helpHtml: Provide a copy of the original park rules.

E016002.title: Revised rules
E016002.helpHtml: Provide a copy of the revised park rules, letters, email, or texts stating new  park rules.

E016003.title: Tenancy agreements
E016003.helpHtml: Provide a copy of the most recent Tenancy Agreement outlining the terms of the tenancy. Include any addendums.

E017001.title: Proof of violation of tenancy laws
E017001.helpHtml: Provide copies of documents (letters, emails, texts, etc.), statements, photos, video or voice recording of how the landlord is violating the BC tenancy laws.

E017002.title: Tenancy agreements
E017002.helpHtml: Provide a copy of the most recent Tenancy Agreement outlining the terms of the tenancy. Include any addendums.

E100001.title: Proof of non-payment(s)
E100001.helpHtml: Provide proof of rent owing. This may include rent ledgers, account statements, written communications with the tenant about unpaid rent, or any other evidence to show the amount of rent owing.

E100002.title: Requests for payment(s)
E100002.helpHtml: Provide any documents requesting rent payment. This could be a letter, email text, or other communications.

E100003.title: Utility payment demand letter(s)
E100003.helpHtml: Provide a copy of the 30 Day Written Demand Letter that was served to the tenant requesting the tenant pay utilities or both rent and utilities. Provide a copy of unpaid utility bills.

E100005.title: Payment plan(s)
E100005.helpHtml: Provide a copy of the Rent Repayment Plan issued to the tenant.

E100006.title: Witness statement/Info
E100006.helpHtml: Provide any previous landlord history, contact info, or evidence that the tenant did not move out after being ordered to do so

E100007.title: Tenancy agreements
E100007.helpHtml: Provide a copy of the most recent Tenancy Agreement outlining the terms of the tenancy. Include any addendums.

E101001.title: Proof of damage
E101001.helpHtml: Provide evidence to prove that the damage was caused by the tenant, their pets, or their guests. Evidence may include proof of the age and original price/cost of items damaged, photos or video recordings of the unit or site before and after damage occurred, receipts or estimates for repairs (receipts are better), expert reports showing repairs were not regular wear and tear, or proof of age of item to be repaired.

E101002.title: Contractor repair reports, assessments, quotes or invoices
E101002.helpHtml: Provide a copy of any qualified contractor (carpenter, plumber, electrician, general contractor, etc.) or architect/engineer reports, assessments, quotes or invoices. If you have completed any repair work yourself, third party verification may be required.

E101003.title: Warning letter(s)
E101003.helpHtml: Provide a copy of any records (documents, letters, emails, texts, etc.) requesting repairs be made before the tenancy ends or ended.

E101004.title: Repair Receipts
E101004.helpHtml: Provide a copy of any receipts or proof of payment costs incurred as a result of the damage. Receipts should have the company name, date and amount paid visible. If you have completed any repair work yourself, third party verification may be required.

E101005.title: Condition Inspection Report
E101005.helpHtml: Provide documentation to verify the condition of the rental unit at the start of the tenancy which may include the Condition Inspection Report (form RTB-27) and, if applicable, at the end of the tenancy.

E101006.title: Witness statement/Info
E101006.helpHtml: Provide any previous landlord history, contact info, or evidence that the tenant did not move out after being ordered to do so

E101007.title: Tenancy agreements
E101007.helpHtml: Provide a copy of the most recent Tenancy Agreement outlining the terms of the tenancy. Include any addendums.

E102001.title: Proof of assignment or sublet
E102001.helpHtml: Provide a copy of any evidence that the tenant has sublet or assigned the rental unit or site.

E102002.title: Sublet or assignment agreements
E102002.helpHtml: Provide a copy of any requests to sublet or assign the tenancy, or any communications regarding assigning or subletting the tenancy.

E102003.title: Tenancy agreements
E102003.helpHtml: Provide a copy of the most recent Tenancy Agreement outlining the terms of the tenancy. Include any addendums.

E103001.title: Decision(s) or order(s)
E103001.helpHtml: Provide a copy of the decision and/or order from the Residential Tenancy Branch.

E103002.title: Proof the tenant has not followed the decision/order
E103002.helpHtml: Provide a copy of any written letter, email, or other communication you gave the tenant informing them that all or parts of a decision or order are outstanding. The Compliance and Enforcement Unit does not enforce orders for possession or money.

E103003.title: Tenancy agreements
E103003.helpHtml: Provide a copy of the most recent Tenancy Agreement outlining the terms of the tenancy. Include any addendums.

E104001.title: Proof of false or misleading information
E104001.helpHtml: Provide copies of the original and false/fraudulent documents. Provide documents or statements that contradict the false/fraudulent evidence provided to the Residential Tenancy Branch.

E104002.title: Proof of false or misleading information was relevant to the decision
E104002.helpHtml: Provide a statement of how the false or misleading information negatively impacted the decision or the Compliance and Enforcement Unit investigation.

E104003.title: Proof of fraudulent intentions
E104003.helpHtml: Provide copies of documents (emails, text, letters, etc.) where the tenant is stating something contrary to the evidence or statement provided to the Residential Tenancy Branch.

E104004.title: Decision(s) or order(s)
E104004.helpHtml: Provide a copy of the decision and/or order from the Residential Tenancy Branch.

E104005.title: RTB dispute documents
E104005.helpHtml: Provide copies of evidence uploaded to the Residential Tenancy Branch Dispute File, relevant to the false or misleading information.

E104006.title: Tenancy agreements
E104006.helpHtml: Provide a copy of the most recent Tenancy Agreement outlining the terms of the tenancy. Include any addendums.

E105001.title: Proof of violation to tenancy laws
E105001.helpHtml: Provide copies of documents (letters, emails, texts, etc.), statements, photos, video or voice recording of how the landlord is violating the BC tenancy laws.

E105002.title: Tenancy agreements
E105002.helpHtml: Provide a copy of the most recent Tenancy Agreement outlining the terms of the tenancy. Include any addendums.
